Extore Class Reference

Reads/Writes bookmarks from/to an external store. More...

#import <Extore.h>

Detailed Description

Reads/Writes bookmarks from/to an external store.

Declares that Extore can handle the messages it will forward to its Starker.

Declaring these in a category is the official trick to eliminate compiler warnings which would otherwise occur where these messages are sent.

Member Function Documentation

- (NSBundle *) browserBundle  

Returns:

- (BOOL) browserInstalledIsOK  

For builtin browfiles, checks if the browser indicated by the receiver's ownerApp is installed on the system, and whether its version meets the minimum requirement of the receiver's minBrowserVersion.

If the receiver's extoreMedia] <= BkmmExtoreBuiltin, returns YES unconditionally.

Parameters:
error_p If result is NO, upon return, will point to an NSError explaining the problem.
Returns:
YES if browser is installed and meets minimum version requirement, NO otherwise.

Tests whether or not a give Starype can be inserted as a child of the root item in the receiver.

Depends on the browser or service.

starype The Starype to be tested
Returns:

- (BOOL) canProbablyInternalizeFileType: (id)  type
data: (id)  data 

Determines whether or not the receiver can probably internalize given data from a given file type.

Subclasses should override. The default implementation returns NO.

Parameters:
type The name of a document type, such as the document types listed in Target > Info > Properties > Document Types > Name
data 
Returns:
YES if it is probable, NO if impossible

+ (const ExtoreConstants *) constants_p  

Returns a pointer to a const struct of constants that define the workings of a particular Extore subclass.

Must be overridden by subclasses. Default implementation raises an exception so do not invoke it.

- (NSMutableDictionary *) defaultFileProperties  

Returns a dictionary of default file properties for the receiver.

Reads this dictionary from a resource named "fPD_XXXX.plist" where XXXX is the exformat of the receiver's browfile. If this resource is not found, logs an error and returns nil.

Returns:
The dictionary read from the resource, or nil.

- (Starype) defaultParentStarypeRank  

Returns the Starype of the parent to which default children should be assigned.

The returned Starype must accept children of any Starype.

Returns:
The Starype of the default parent for this extore.

- (NSString *) definingFilePath  

Returns the receiver's filePath or filePathParent, whichever is first not nil, in that order.

OmniWeb returns filePathParent instead of filePath since it stores bookmarks in three separate files in there.

Returns:
A POSIX path

+ (NSSet *) despoofedTagSetFromTagSet: (NSSet*)  tags  

Given a tag set, if delimiter spoofs are found, replaces them.

Tag delimiters are replaced by the underscore, "_". If no tag delimiters are found in any member of tags, returns nil. This is to allow efficient invokers to skip extra work if tags are OK as is.

Parameters:
tags The set of tags to be checked for spoofs
Returns:
If delimiter spoofs were found in one or more of the input tags, a copy of the input tags with all spoofs replaced. If no spoofs were found in the input tags, returns nil.

- (BOOL) externalWasTouchedSinceLastInternalized  

Returns whether or not the external store was touched since the receiver last internalized the external store's data.

Gets a current value for the receiver's lastDateExternalWasTouched and compares it with it's browfile's lastInternalized. If either number is not available, returns the "worst case" answer of YES.

Returns:
YES if the receiver's data is "out of sync" with the external store, NO if the receiver's data is current/OK.

+ (Class) extoreClassForExformat: (NSString*)  exformat  

Returns the Extore subclass for a given exformat.

Parameters:
exformat The exformat (external format) for which the Extore subclass is desired. Should be one of the members you get from either +[BrowfileCapabilities supportedLocalAppExformats] or +[BrowfileCapabilities supportedWebAppExformats].
Returns:
A Class object

+ (id) extoreWithBrowfile: (Browfile*)  browfile_
deference: (BkmmDeference)  deference_ 

Convenience method for returning an autoreleased extore of the subclass given by the browfile's -extoreClass.

Parameters:
browfile_ The owning Browfile, kept as a weak reference by the returned Extore.
deference_ The level of deference that the receiver will use if an operation it is tasked to perform is not allowed due to a running nasty browser.

- (NSString *) filePathParent  

Returns the path to the parent directory containing the receiver's browser's bookmarks file or files, or nil if the receiver's browser does not have a single bookmarks file.

For a web service, returns the path on the server at which the bookmarks API is accessed.

- (NSString *) freshExternalIdentifierForStark: (Stark*)  item
tryHard: (BOOL)  tryHard 

Returns a new and different stark identifier for a stark which is unique among the receiver's starks.

The default implementation returns the next UUID using CFUUID, with dashes in it. This is appropriate for Safari and Camino. Subclasses for which this is not appropriate should override.

Parameters:
item The item for which the fresh identifier is desired. Most stores ignore this parameter
tryHard If getting a fresh identifier would be costly, such as having to contact a remote server, tryHard tells the method whether or not to do that.
Returns:
The new identifier

- (id) initWithBrowfile: (Browfile*)  browfile_
deference: (BkmmDeference)  deference_ 

Designated Initializer.

Will initialize the subclass of Extore given by the browfile's -extoreClass. Do not send this message to Extore because the Extore class is useless. Send it to a subclass of Extore.

Parameters:
browfile_ The owning Browfile, kept as a weak reference by the receiver.
deference_ The level of deference that the receiver will use if an operation it is tasked to perform is not allowed due to a running nasty browser.

- (NSDate *) lastDateExternalWasTouched  

Returns the last date that the external store was modified.

If the date cannot be found, returns the current date, since this will cause the "worst case" answer of "yes" to the question "Has the external data been modified so recently that I must re-read it?"

Default implmentation returns the most recent file modification date of [self filePath]. This works for the most common case, which is if the owning browser is a local app (as opposed to a web app) that also stores bookmarks in a single file.

Subclasses should override if a web app provides such a date, or if three files must be tested, as with OmniWeb.

+ (NSString *) legendForKey: (NSString*)  key  

Parameters:
key 
Returns:

- (NSString *) ownerAppFullPath  

Returns either the full path to the receiver's ownerApp if it is installed as a desktop application, or a URL to the receiver's API if it is a web service application, or nil.

Returns nil if the receiver -ownerAppIsLocalApp but is not installed.

- (BOOL) readExternalDoingPrereqs  

Reads bookmarks data from the external store, checking prerequisites and performing related housekeeping operations.

If a ownerAppNiceness requirement is not satisfied, dialogs with user to allow quitting of the browser or cancelling of the operation. Sets the receiver's error if any user cancels or if anything else goes wrong.

Returns:
YES if the operation was successful, otherwise NO.

- (BOOL) readExternalNoPrereqs  

Gets bookmarks data from the external store and writes Starks to the receiver's exterMOC and to its localMOC (the latter only if this extore uses it), assuming prerequisites have already been verified.

Sets the receiver's error if any user cancels or if anything else goes wrong. Default implementation logs an Internal Error. Subclasses must override.

Returns:
YES if the operation was successful, otherwise NO.

+ (NSSet *) spooflessTagSetFromTagSet: (NSSet*)  tags  

Replaces delimiter spoofs in a tag set.

Tag delimiters are replaced by the underscore, "_". If no tag delimiters are found in any member of tags, returns the given tags set.

Parameters:
tags The set of tags to be checked for spoofs
Returns:
If delimiter spoofs were found in one or more of the input tags, a copy of the input tags with all spoofs replaced. If no spoofs were found in the input tags, returns the input tags.

- (Stark *) starkFromExtoreItem: (id)  item  

Returns a new stark modelling a given item from the external store.

Subclasses must override. Default implementation logs an Internal Error and returns nil.

Parameters:
item The item from the external store to be modelled.
Returns:
The new stark

+ (NSString *) tagDelimiter  

Returns the constant tag delimiter for this extore's exformat.

Returns:
The tag delimiter, a 1-character string

+ (NSSet *) tagSetFromString: (NSString*)  string  

Parses a string and returns the tags found as an NSSet.

This method is used in importing from browser/services that store tags as a string. The tags in 'string' are assumed to be joined by the receiver's tagDelimiter, and any whitespace adjacent to the delimiters is ignored, as are empty strings or strings of whitespace onl between consecutive delimiters. Delimiter spoofs in the string must be removed or disallowed by design before invoking this method.

Parameters:
string The string which is to be parsed for tags
Returns:
The set of tags found, an empty set if 'string' is an empty string, or nil if 'string' is nil.

+ (NSString *) tagStringFromSet: (NSSet*)  set  

Returns a string containing the tags in a given set.

This method is used in exporting to browser/services that store tags as a string. The tags in the returned string are joined by two characters: the receiver's tagDelimiter, followed by a space. The tags are not checked for delimiter spoofs. Delimiter spoofs must be removed or disallowed by design before invoking this method.

Parameters:
set The set of tags to be used in creating the string. Actually, this may be any set of NSString objects.
Returns:
The string containing the tags, or an empty string if set is nil or empty.

- (NSSet *) watchPaths  

Returns a set of paths which should be watched to see when the receiver's web browser has either changed its bookmarks or quit.

Usually, the result contains only a single path, but sometimes some browsers may require two, since one path may change when the bookmarks are changed and another may change when the browser is quit. However, if the the browser does not allow changes to its bookmarks while it is running, that is if OwnerAppNiceness is less than OwnerAppNicenessAllowsWriting, then only one path, which should be watched to signal when the ownerApp has quit, will be returned.

- (BOOL) writeData: (NSData*)  data
toFile: (NSString*)  path 

Writes data to a file atomically.

A wrapper around -[NSData writeToFile:atomically] which first checks if the file can be written and tries to set the receiver's -error if something goes wrong. This may be used by subclasses which require simple atomic writing of bookmarks file(s) such as Safari, Camino, Opera and OmniWeb.

Parameters:
data The data to be put in the file.
path The path of the file to be written.
Returns:
YES if the operation was successful, otherwise NO.

- (BOOL) writeExternalNoPrereqs  

Writes bookmarks data from the receiver's exterMOC to its external store and to its localMOC (the latter only if this extore uses it), assuming prerequisites have already been verified.

Sets the receiver's error if any user cancels or if anything else goes wrong.

Default implementation logs an Internal Error.  Subclasses must override.

Returns:
YES if the operation was successful, otherwise NO.

- (void) writeExternalWithPrereqsForBmxBk: (BmxBk*)  bmxBk  

Writes bookmarks data to the external store, checking prerequisites and performing related housekeeping operations.

Sets the receiver's error if any user cancels or if anything else goes wrong. No return value because threading will be used if GUI and not running under AppleScript command.

Parameters:
bmxBk The bmxBk from which bookmarks data should be written.

Property Documentation

- (NSError *) error [read, write, retain]

The receiver's error object.

The receiver's error object is a convenience for methods in the class to communicate errors to one another, without having to pass around an NSError** argument. It should be set to nil at the beginning of a task. Since it is a declared property, conformers of this protocol may implement it simply by error ;
